Draft of Tip: In 1989, Rep. Barney Frank, D-Mass., had a lengthy relationship with a male hooker who ran a bisexual prostitution service out of Frank's apartment.
In 1996, Rep. Dan Rostenkowski, D-Ill., was convicted on corruption charges for laundering money through stamps and postal vouchers.
Bill Clinton adviser Dick Morris frequented a prostitute in the mid-1990s at the Jefferson Hotel and allowed her to eavesdrop on phone calls with the President.
The long time mistress of Rep. Don Sherwood, R-Pa., locked herself in the bathroom of his home and called 911, alleging the congressman strangled her.
In 2008, former New York Governor Eliot Spitzer had an affair with a $1,000+-an-hour prostitute in Room 871 of the Mayflower Hotel.

In 2001, then-congressman Gary Condit, D-Calif., allowed police to search his apartment after misleading them about an affair he had with his intern Chandra Levy, who had recently disappeared. He was spotted disposing a gift box hours before police entered the premises.
Address: 2600 Adams Mill Rd NW, Washington, DC

Draft of Tip: In 2002, the body of Chandra Levy was found in Rock Creek Park after a high-profile investigation that led to revelations of an affair between the Hill intern and former congressman Gary Condit, D-Calif.
Address: Western Ridge Trail - Rock Creek Park, Washington, DC

Draft of Tip: The apartment building where murdered Hill intern Chandra Levy lived and the possible meeting spot for her affair with Rep. Gary Condit, D-Calif.
Address: Newport Condominium - 1260 21st St. NW, Washington, DC

Draft of Tip: In 1987, a woman was seen leaving the Washington residence of recently-announced presidential candidate Gary Hart. Photos of the two of them on the luxury yacht, Monkey Business, led to Hart pulling out of the race.
Signatures was a short-lived restaurant run by superlobbyist and convicted criminal Jack Abramoff that served as another medium to funnel money from clients to politicians.

The now-defunct Alexander Strategy Group was a lobbying shop that worked closely with superlobbyist Jack Abramoff, former Rep. Randy 'Duke' Cunningham, R-Calif., and former Republican House majority leader Tom DeLay -- all convicted criminals for various levels of corruption.

The site of Eshkol Academy, a defunct Orthodox Jewish day school for boys founded by superlobbyist and convicted criminal Jack Abramoff in 2002. The school was largely funded by laundered money through Abramoff's Capital Athletic Foundation.

Americans for Tax Reform was one of the non-profits implicated in the Jack Abramoff scandal in 2006. Its leaders allegedly laundered funds from Abramoff clients in exchange for favorable publicity and connections with high level officials, including then-President George W. Bush.

The site of the Capital Athletic Foundation, a 501(c)(3) organization founded in 2000 by superlobbyist and convicted criminal Jack Abramoff. It was a major money laundering operation that distributed funds to Abramoff's various activities.
Address: 1101 Pennsylvania Ave NW Ste. 600, Washington, DC

Draft of Tip: The Council of Republicans for Environmental Advocacy was one of the profits implicated in the Jack Abramoff scandal. Its leaders allegedly laundered funds from Abramoff clients in exchange for favorable publicity and connections with high level officials.
Place: Council of Republicans for Environmental Advocacy
Link: AP - 'Fundraiser pleads guilty in lobby probe' also: http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/10/12/AR2006101200889.html

Draft of Tip: The site of GrassRoots Interactive, a now-defunct lobbying shop controlled by Jack Abramoff that was implicated in a network of political corruption.
Address: NO SPECIFIC ADDRESS KNOWN - Silver Spring, MD

Draft of Tip: The home of former superlobbyist and convicted criminal Jack Abramoff that at one time served as the business address for KayGold LLC, a front group he used to funnel money into his personal accounts.
The site of KayGold LLC, a front group of former superlobbyist and convicted criminal Jack Abramoff that was used to funnel lobbying fees into his personal accounts.
Jack Abramoff, former superlobbyist and convicted criminal, worked at Preston Gates & Ellis (now known as Kirkpatrick & Lockhart Preston Gates Ellis LLP) as a lobbyist from 1994 to 2001.
Place: Preston Gates & Ellis (now known as Kirkpatrick & Lockhart Preston Gates Ellis LLP)

Draft of Tip: The site of the U.S. Family Network, a tax-exempt 501(c)(4) organization deeply involved with former superlobbyist and convicted criminal Jack Abramoff. USFN was largely funded by Abramoff clients and included a 15-year lease on a Redskins skybox that was frequently used by Abramoff.

The site of Capitol Campaign Strategies, a public relations firm founded in 2001 by Michael Scanlon, Tom DeLay's former press secretary and Jack Abramoff's partner. The organization defrauded Native American tribes of millions of dollars in the corruption scheme to split billings 50/50 with Abramoff. The pair referred to it as 'Gimme Five.'

In 2006, Rep. Mark Foley, R-Fla., sent sexually suggestive instant messages to teenaged boys who had formerly served as congressional pages. The ensuing scandal included members of the Republican leadership who sought to hamper the investigation.
In the mid-1990s then-House Speaker Newt Gingrich had an affair with staffer Callista Bisek while leading the charge into President Clinton infidelities.
Scandal (not public facing): Newt Gingrich Cheating with Staffer Scandal

Draft of Tip: Current federal inmate and former congressman Randy "Duke" Cunningham lived in a yacht here, owned by a defense contractor. He even secured earmarks to renovate the area.

Current federal inmate and former congressman Randy "Duke" Cunningham frequented the Westin Grand Hotel with prostitutes and a limo, all provided by a defense contractor that Cunningham helped get multi-million dollar contracts.

CACI-Athena, Inc., formerly known as MZM, Inc., was founded by Mitchell Wade, who admitted to bribing former congressman Randy "Duke" Cunningham with more than $1 million including cash, antiques and payment for yachts to obtain lucrative defense contracts.
Address: 1523 New Hampshire Ave. NW, Washington, DC

Draft of Tip: Citronelle was the site of a $2,800 meal where defense contractor Mitchell Wade gave former congresswoman Katherine Harris a campaign contribution in exchange for a promise to earmark a $10 million contract.
Rep. Jerry Lewis, R-Calif., has earmarked $2.75 million federal dollars since 2004 to the Barracks Row neighborhood where he owns a three-bedroom house.
Address: Barracks Row, 8th street SE, Washington DC
Scandal (not public facing): The Rep. Jerry Lewis and  former-Rep. Lowery (now lobbyist) controversy

Draft of Tip: In 1976 it was revealed that Rep. Wayne L. Hays, D-Ohio, kept his mistress on his staff as a clerk with a private office. She admitted she couldn't type, file or answer a phone.
Address: Longworth House Office Building Room 1506P, Washington, DC

Draft of Tip: In 1974 a car was pulled over near the Jefferson Memorial for not using headlights. The vehicle contained an intoxicated Rep. Wilbur Mills, D-Ariz., and Fanne Foxe, a well known local stripper, who promptly leaped from the car into the Tidal Basin.
Former Rep. William J. Jefferson, D-La., stuffed cash for bribes into the freezer of his Washington DC home. He is now serving the longest sentence ever given to a member of Congress.

On June 17, 1972 five men were arrested after infiltrating the 6th floor headquarters of the Democratic National Committee at the Watergate complex. The details of the professional break-in eventually uncovered connections to the highest levels of Richard Nixon's administration, leading to the only resignation of a U.S. president in history.
Address: Watergate 2600 Virginia Ave. NW, Washington, DC

Draft of Tip: In 1972, this address served as the headquarters for the Committee to Re-elect the President, a fundraising organization for President Richard Nixon that played an active role in the Watergate scandal. CRP (also known as CREEP) paid the legal expenses of the Watergate burglars in exchange for their silence, which eventually led to the unraveling of the scandal that ended with Nixon's resignation.
Place: Offices of the Committee to Re-elect the President

Draft of Tip: In 1972, Washington Post reporter Bob Woodward met with former FBI official Mark Felt (also known as "Deep Throat") in parking space 34D on the bottom level of this parking garage. Felt provided key information to the Washington Post to reveal a scandal that eventually led to the resignation of President Nixon.
Place: Meeting place of Bob Woodward and "Deep Throat"/Mark Felt
Address: Parking space 34D, 1401 Wilson Blvd, Arlington, VA 22209

Draft of Tip: In 1972, apartment 617 at this location belonged to Washington Post reporter Bob Woodward. If his contact Mark Felt (also known as 'Deep Throat') wanted to meet, Felt would mark Woodward's morning paper with a code indicating a meeting time.
Address: Apartment 617, 1718 P Street NW, Washington, DC

Draft of Tip: In the 1970s Republican political operative Harry Dent ran a slush fund out of this Dupont Circle townhouse. It was used to make donations to political candidates with the intent of later blackmailing them. Dent pleaded guilty to the operation of campaign finance abuses in 1974 after it came to light during the Watergate investigation.
Place: Townhouse headquarters of slush fund to blackmail Nixon opponents

Draft of Tip: In 1978 this was the home of Washington Post reporter Lee Lescaze, who unknowingly rented the place to the FBI for the Abscam sting, where five House members and a senator were busted for bribery and corruption.
Place: Townhouse where Abscam sting took place

Draft of Tip: In the late 60s a South Korean businessman named Tongsun Park founded the George Town Club with the help of millions of dollars from the Korean government. The club established an unofficial lobbying center that would funnel funds to influence U.S. politicians. Among the many events held there, Park threw a lavish birthday party for then-House majority leader Thomas P. 'Tip' O'Neill. About 115 members of Congress were eventually swept up in the scandal dubbed 'Koreagate'.
Place: Private club in Georgetown founded by Tongsun Park that was used to influence members of Congress.
column9: Page 61-66 of Gifts of Deceit - Robert Boettcher

Draft of Tip: In 1980 Robert Bauman, a conservative House member from Maryland, was arrested by the FBI for soliciting and paying $50 to engage in sexual relations with a 16-year-old boy starting at the Chesapeake House, a now-defunct bar in Chinatown.
Place: Former location of the Chesapeake House - a gay bar frequented by conservative former Rep. Bob Bauman
Scandal (not public facing): Rep. Bauman solicited sex from a teenager
Link: WaPo - 10/4/1980 - 'Bauman Pleads Innocent on Solicitation Charge'

Draft of Tip: 1625 K Street was once the famous 'Little Green House on K Street' where political corruption and cronyism thrived in the early 20th century. President Harding's Ohio Gang of powerful friends hatched the plans of the Teapot Dome scandal here.
Place: Site of 'The Little Green House on K Street' - headquarters of the Ohio Gang from the Harding Administration
Scandal (not public facing): Little Green House on K Street

Draft of Tip: The former Washington DC offices of Arthur Anderson LLP, the accounting firm that audited Enron - the defunct Texas energy company. Arthur Anderson was found guilty of obstruction of justice for shredding documents.
Place: Former office of Arthur Andersen LLP
